content (Sutra, Meaning, and Key Analysi: Sutra: वायु पित्तं कफश्चेति त्रयों समासतः .... Meaning: Vāta, Pitta, and Kapha are the three Doshas. When vitiated (vikrita), they cause harm; when balanced, they maintain and nourish the body. Analysis: Vāta is below the navel, Pitta between the navel and the heart, and Kapha above the heart.

Sutra: वयो ऽ होरात्रिभुक्तानां तेडन्तमध्यादिगाः क्रमात्. Meaning: Vāta predominates in old age, Pitta in youth, and Kapha in childhood. In a day, Kapha is dominant in the morning, Pitta at noon, and Vāta at the end of the day. Analysis: Kapha (sweet/acid) is high while eating, Pitta (acidic) during digestion, and Vāyu (motion) after digestion.

Sutra: तैर्भवेद्विषमस्तीक्ष्णो मन्दश्रवाग्निः समैः सम. Meaning: Vāta makes the digestive fire irregular (Viṣama); Pitta makes it intense (Tīkṣṇa); Kapha makes it weak (Manda). If Doshas are equal (Sama), the fire is balanced.

Sutra: कोष्ठः क्रूरो मदुर्भध्यो मध्यः स्यात्तैः समैरपि. Meaning: Vāta causes a hard/constipated bowel movement (Krūra); Pitta causes a soft one (Mṛdu); Kapha causes a moderate one (Madhya). Equal Doshas result in a moderate bowel.

Sutra: शुक्रार्तवस्थैर्जन्मादो विषेनेव विषक्रिमेः. Meaning: Prakṛti is formed by the predominance of Doshas in the sperm and ovum at conception. The best constitution is the one with balanced Doshas (Sama). Analysis: Vāta Prakṛti should avoid dry, cold environments; Pitta Prakṛti should avoid heating substances; Kapha Prakṛti should avoid heavy, unctuous substances.

Sutra: तत्र रूक्षो लघुः शीतः खरः सूक्ष्मश्रलोडनिलः. Meaning: Vāyu has the qualities of dryness (Rūkṣa), lightness (Lagu), coldness (Śīta), roughness (Khara), subtlety (Sūkṣma), and being constantly moving (Calāyamāna). Analysis: Vāyu is increased by dry, cold substances and motion, and reduced by unctuous substances like oil and stability.

Sutra: पित्तं सस्नेहतीक्ष्णोष्णं लघु विस्त्रं सरं द्रवम्. Meaning: Pitta has slight unctuousness, sharpness (Tīkṣṇa), heat (Uṣṇa), lightness (Lagu), fetid smell (Visra), mobility (Sara), and liquidity (Drava).

Sutra: स्निग्धः शीतोगुरूर्मन्दः श्लक्ष्नो मृत्स्नः स्थिरः कफः. Meaning: Kapha has unctuousness (Snigdha), coldness (Śītal), heaviness (Guru), slowness/mildness (Manda), smoothness (Ślakṣṇa), earth-like smell (Mṛtsna), and stability (Sthira).

Sutra: रसासृझ्यांसमेदोऽस्थिमज्जशुक्राणि धातवः । सप्त दूष्याः- मला मूत्रशकृत्स्वेदादयोऽपिच. Meaning: The seven Dhatus (Rasa, Rakta, Māṃsa, Meda, Asthi, Majjā, Śukra) are vitiated by Doshas. Stool (Śakṛt), Urine (Mūtra), and Sweat (Sveda) are Malas (Wastes).
Sutra: वृद्धिः समानैः सर्वेषां विपरीतैविपर्ययः. Meaning: Doshas, Dhatus, and Malas are increased by similar substances, qualities, and actions, and decreased by contrary (opposite) ones.

Sutra: रसाः स्वाद्वम्ललवणत्तिकोषणकषायकाः शड् द्रव्यमाश्रितास्ते च यथापूर्व बलावहाः. Meaning: The six Tastes are Sweet (Svadū), Sour (Amla), Salty (Lavaṇa), Pungent (Tikta), Hot/Pungent (Kaṭu), and Astringent (Kaṣāya). The preceding taste is sequentially more potent. Analysis: Sweet taste (Earth+Water) nourishes the body the most.

Sutra: तत्राद्या मारूतं धन्ति त्रयस्तिदायः कफम्। कषायतिक्तमधुराः पित्तमन्ये तु कुर्वते. Meaning (Pacifying): Sweet, Sour, Salty pacify Vāta. Pungent, Bitter, Astringent pacify Kapha. Astringent, Bitter, Sweet pacify Pitta. Meaning (Aggravating): Bitter, Hot/Pungent, Astringent increase Vāta. Sweet, Sour, Salty increase Kapha. Sour, Salty, Hot/Pungent increase Pitta.

Sutra: त्रिधा विपाको द्रव्यस्य स्वाद्वम्लकटुकात्मकः. Meaning: Vipāka (taste after digestion) is of three types: Sweet (Svadū), Sour (Amla), and Pungent (Kaṭu). Analysis: Sweet and Salty taste becomes Sweet Vipāka. Sour taste remains Sour Vipāka. Pungent, Bitter, and Astringent tastes become Pungent Vipāka.

Sutra: कालार्थकर्मणां योगो हीनमिध्याऽतिमात्रकः । सम्यग्योश्च विज्ञेयो रोगो रोग्यैक कारणम्. Meaning: Proper combination (Samyak Yoga) of Time (Kāla), Senses (Artha), and Action (Karma) causes health. Improper combination (Heena, Mithyā, Ati Yoga) is the single cause of disease. Analysis: Examples of Mithyā Yoga: Hearing unpleasant words, touching incompatible substances, or eating rotten/incompatible food.
Sutra: रोगस्तु दोषवैषम्यं, दोषसाम्यमरोगता. Meaning: The imbalance (Vaiṣamya) of the Doshas is Disease (Roga), and the equilibrium (Sāmya) of the Doshas is Health (Ārogya).

Sutra: ब्राहृमें मुहूर्त उत्तिष्ठेत् स्वस्थो रक्षार्थमायुषः. Meaning: A healthy person should wake up during Brahma Muhurta (early morning, around 4 AM) to protect their lifespan. After focusing on bodily needs (Shārīra Chintā), they should perform purification (Śauca Vidhi).

Sutra: अर्कन्यग्रोधखदिरकरन्ज ककु भादिजम्.... Meaning: Dental sticks from trees like Arka, Nyagrodha, Khadira, etc., should be used. The stick should be astringent (Kaṣāya), pungent (Kaṭu), or bitter (Tikta) in taste, 12 Angulas long, and the thickness of the little finger.

Sutra: नाद्यादजीर्णणमयुश्वासकासज्वरार्दिती । तृष्णा ऽऽस्यपाकहन्नेत्रशिरः कर्णामयीच तत्. Meaning: Dental brushing should not be performed by persons suffering from Indigestion (Ajīrṇa), Vomiting, Dyspnea, Cough, Fever, Facial Paralysis, Thirst, Stomatitis, Heart Disease, Eye Disease, Headache, and Ear Disease. Analysis: Brushing increases salivation, which aids digestion and cleanses the stomach; in these diseases, this is counter-productive.

Sutra: सौवीरमन्जनं नित्यं हितमक्ष्णोस्ततो भजेत्.... Meaning: One should apply Sauvīra Añjana (Collyrium/Surma) daily, as the eyes (fiery/Āgneya) are threatened by Kapha (Śleṣmā). Rasāñjana should be applied once every seven nights to promote more discharge (Kapha flow).

Sutra: अभ्यडं. गमाचरे नित्यं स जराश्रमवातहा.... Meaning: Oil massage must be performed daily. It prevents aging, removes fatigue (Śrama), pacifies Vāta, and promotes longevity. It should be specially practiced on the head (Śiras), ears (Śravaṇa), and feet (Pāda). Analysis: Oil massage on the head destroys Kapha (hot/subtle oil); in the ears, it balances Vāyu; on the feet, it prevents cracked heels from Vāyu dryness.

Sutra: वर्योडयड़ङ्गः कफग्रस्तकृतसंशृद्धयजार्णिभिः. Meaning: Oil massage should not be performed by those suffering from Kapha-born diseases, those who have undergone purification therapy (Śodhana), or those suffering from Indigestion (Ajīrṇa).

Sutra: लाघवं कर्मसामर्थ्य दीप्तोऽग्निर्मेदसः क्षयः.... Meaning: Exercise brings lightness (Lāghava), capacity for work, kindles the digestive fire (Dīpto 'Agni), reduces fat tissue (Medas), and strengthens body parts.

Sutra: वातपित्तामयी बालो वृद्धीऽजीर्णी च तं त्यजेत्. Meaning: Patients suffering from Vāta and Pitta disorders, children (up to age 10), the elderly, and patients with Indigestion (Ajīrṇa) should avoid exercise. Analysis: Exercise increases Vāta and Pitta. In children, it decreases Kapha, which is needed for growth. In Ajīrṇa, it reduces Kapha and causes agitation needed for digestion.

Sutra: अर्धशक्तया निषेव्यस्तु बलिभि स्निग्धभोजिभिः.... Meaning: Exercise should be practiced only up to half their capacity (Ardha Śakti) by strong people who consume unctuous foods (Snigdha Bhojinaḥ) like ghee and milk. It should be done during cold season and spring, and less in other seasons. The body should be massaged afterward.

Sutra: तृष्णा क्षयः प्रतमको रक्तपित्तं श्रमः क्लमः.... Meaning: Excessive exercise causes increased thirst (Tṛṣṇā), tissue wasting (Kṣaya), bleeding disorders (Raktapitta), fatigue, cough, fever, and vomiting.
Sutra: उद्वर्तनं कफहरं मेदसः प्रविलामनम्. Meaning: Massaging with a scrub (Udvartaṇa) pacifies Kapha, liquefies fat (Medas), strengthens body parts, and makes the skin beautiful.

Sutra: दीपनं वृष्यमायुष्यं स्नानमुजबिलप्रदम्.... Meaning: Bathing kindles the digestive fire (Dīpana), is aphrodisiac, increases longevity, and provides energy and strength. It conquers itching, dirt, fatigue, sweat, lethargy, thirst, heat, and sin. Analysis: Pouring warm water over the lower part of the body gives strength, but pouring it over the head destroys the strength of the hair and eyes. Bathing should be done before eating.

Sutra: स्नानमर्दित नेत्रास्यकर्व रोगा तिसारिषु.... Meaning: Bathing is prohibited for those suffering from Facial Paralysis (Ardita), Eye diseases, Mouth diseases, Ear diseases, Diarrhea (Atisāra), Indigestion (Ajīrṇa), and after eating (Bhuktavatsu). Analysis: Bathing increases Vāyu (bad for Ardita, ear diseases) and Pitta (bad for eye diseases, Atisāra), and weakens the digestive fire (bad for Ajīrṇa, after eating).

Sutra: जीर्णे हितं भितं चाद्यान्न वेगानीरयेद् बलात्.... Meaning: One should only eat beneficial (Hita) and measured (Mita) food after the previously consumed food has been digested (Jīrṇa). One should not forcefully expel (Udirana) or suppress (Dharana) the natural urges (Vegas) for urine, stool, etc.. Analysis: Defect in digestion is the root cause of all diseases. Forcefully expelling or suppressing urges vitiates Vāyu (Apāna Vāyu).

Sutra: सुखार्थाः सर्वभूतानां मताः सर्वाः प्रवृत्तयः । सुखं च न बिना धर्मात्तस्माद्धर्मपरो भवेत्. Meaning: All beings seek happiness (Sukha), which is not possible without Dharma (righteous conduct), so one should always follow Dharma (Virtuous Conduct/Sadvṛtta).

Sutra: वेगान्न धारयेद्वातविण्मूत्रक्षवतृट्क्षुधाम् । निद्राकासश्रमश्वासजृम्भाऽश्रुच्छर्दिरेतसाम्. Meaning: One should not suppress the 13 urges: Flatus (Apāna Vāyu), Stool, Urine, Sneeze, Thirst, Hunger, Sleep, Cough, Exertional Breathlessness, Yawn, Tears, Vomiting, and Semen. Analysis: Suppression causes almost all types of diseases.

Sutra: अधोवातस्य रोधेन गुल्मोदावर्तरूक्‌क्लमाः.... Meaning: Suppressing flatus causes abdominal tumor (Gulma), upward movement of Vāyu (Udāvartta), pain, heart disease (Hṛdgadāḥ), and obstruction of stool and urine. Treatment: Oleation (Sneha), sudation (Svedana), suppositories (Varttī), and food/drinks that facilitate the downward movement of Vāyu (Vātā-nulomana).

Sutra: शकृतः पिण्डिकोद्वेष्टप्रतिश्यायशिरोरूजः.... Meaning: Suppressing stool causes cramps in the calf muscles, coryza, headache, upward movement of Vāyu, obstruction of heart function, and passage of stool through the mouth. Treatment: Suppositories, oil massage below the navel, Vāta-pacifying bath/sudation, enemas (Basti), and food/drink that loosen the stool (Bhedi).

Sutra: अछ्रभङ्गाश्मरीवस्तिमेढ्वगंक्षणवेदनाः.... Meaning: Suppressing urine causes breaking pain in the limbs (Aṅga-bhaṅga), stone formation (Aśmarī), and pain in the bladder, urinary organs, and groin. Treatment: Drinking ghee (Ghṛta-pāna) before the meal (Prāg-bhakta) in the Jīrṇāntika dose (when the previous food is fully digested).

Sutra: शोषाछ्रसादबाधिर्यसम्मोहम्रमहृद्गदाः. Meaning: Suppressing thirst causes dryness of the mouth (Śoṣa), weakness of the limbs, deafness, delusion, dizziness, and heart disease. Treatment: All procedures should involve cold substances (Śītaḥ Sarvo Vidhiḥ Hitaḥ) for bathing, drinking, and food.

Sutra: प्रगभगारूचिग्लानिकार्श्यशूलभ्रमाः क्षुधः. Meaning: Suppressing hunger causes pain in the limbs (Aṅga-bhaṅga), anorexia, fatigue, emaciation, pain in the colon, and dizziness. Treatment: Consume light (Lagu), unctuous (Snigdha), warm (Uṣṇa), and small quantities of food.

Sutra: निद्राया मोहमूर्धाक्षिगौरवालस्यजृम्भिकाः. Meaning: Suppressing sleep causes delusion/mental restlessness (Moha), heaviness in the head and eyes, lethargy, yawning, and pain in the limbs. Treatment: Sleep (Svapna) and body massage (Saṃvāhana) with oil.

Sutra: विसर्पकोठकुष्ठाक्षिकण्डूपाण्ड्वामयज्वराः.... Meaning: Suppressing vomiting causes erysipelas (Visarpa), urticarial rashes (Koṭha), skin diseases, fever, cough, shortness of breath, nausea, and swelling all over the body. Treatment: Gargling, medicated smoking, fasting, eating dry food and then inducing vomiting again, exercise, and purgation.

Sutra: शुक्रात्त्स्त्रवणं गृह्मवेदनाश्वयथुज्वराः.... Meaning: Suppressing semen causes excessive discharge, pain and swelling in the penis, fever, heart pain, urinary retention, pain in the limbs, scrotal enlargement, and impotence. Treatment: Consuming milk medicated with bladder-cleansing drugs (e.g., Gōkṣura) and engaging in sexual intercourse with a loving woman (Priyāḥ Striyaḥ).

Sutra: धारयेतु सदा देगान् हितैशी प्रेत्य चेह च। लोभेष्यद्विषेमात्सर्यरागादीनां जितेन्द्रियः. Meaning: A self-controlled person should always suppress the urges for greed (Lobha), envy (Īrṣyā), hatred (Dveṣa), jealousy (Mātsarya), and attachment/passion (Rāga), among others.

Sutra: दोषाः कदाचित्कुप्यन्ति जिता लंघनपाचनैः । ये तु संशोधनैः शुद्धा न तेशां पुनरूद्भवः. Meaning: Doshas controlled by fasting (Laṅghana) or digestion-promoting (Pācana) therapies may recur. However, Doshas purified by cleansing therapies (Saṃśodhana) do not recur.

Sutra: नित्यं हिताहारविहारसेवी समीक्ष्यकारी विषयेष्वसक्तः । दाता समः सत्यपरः क्षमावा- नाप्तोपसेवी च भवत्यरोगः. Meaning: A person who follows beneficial food/lifestyle, acts after deliberation, is unattached to senses, is charitable, equanimous, truthful, forgiving, and serves the trustworthy remains free from disease (Arogaḥ).

Sutra: जोवनं तर्पणं हृद्यं द्वादि बृद्धिप्रबोधनम्.... Meaning: Pure water (Gāṅga Ambu) sustains life (Jīvana), satisfies (Tarpaṇa), is beneficial for the heart (Hṛdya), is clear, has no perceptible taste, is sweet, cold (Śīta), light (Lagu), and beneficial like nectar.

Sutra: नम्बुपेयमशक्या वा स्वल्पमल्पाग्निगुल्मिभिः । पाण्डुदरातिसारार्शों ग्रहणीशोषशोथिभिः. Meaning: Water should not be drunk (or only a small amount if necessary) by patients with weak digestive fire (Alpāgni), Gulma, Anemia (Pāṇḍu), Abdominal Diseases (Udara), Diarrhea (Atisāra), Piles, Malabsorption (Grahaṇī), Consumption (Śoṣa), and Swelling (Śotha).

Sutra: समस्थूलकृशा भुक्तमध्यान्तप्रथमाम्बुपाः. Meaning: Persons who drink water at the beginning of the meal become emaciated (Kṛśa), in the middle become well-proportioned (Sama), and at the end become obese (Sthūla).

Sutra: शीतं मदात्ययग्लानिमूर्छाच्छर्दिश्रमम्रमान् । तृष्णोष्रगदाहपित्तास्त्रविषाण्यम्बू नियच्छति. Meaning: Cold water (Śīta Ambu) cures alcoholism (Madātyaya), fatigue, fainting, vomiting, exhaustion, dizziness, increased thirst, heat, burning sensation (Dāha), bleeding disorders (Pittāsra), and poisoning.

Sutra: दीपनं पाचनं कण्ठयं लघूष्णंवस्तिशोधनम् । हिध्माध्मानानिलश्लेश्मसद्यः शुद्धिनवज्वरे.... Meaning: Hot water (Uṣṇa Ambu) kindles digestive fire (Dīpana), aids digestion (Pācana), is good for the throat, light, warm, and cleanses the bladder. It is beneficial in hiccup, flatulence, Vāta and Kapha diseases, new fevers (Nava Jvara), cough, and shortness of breath.

sutra_name: Qualities of Boiled and Cooled Water
content (Sutra, Meaning, and Key Analysi: Sutra: अनभिष्यन्दि लघु च तोयं क्वथितशीतलम् । पितयुक्ते हितं दोषे, व्युषितं तत्त्रिदोषकृत्. Meaning: Water that has been boiled and cooled is non-clogging and light. It is beneficial in Dosha combinations that include Pitta. Stale (Vyuṣita) boiled water aggravates the three Doshas.

Sutra: अत्र गव्यं तु जीवनीयं रसायनम् । क्षतक्षीणहितं मेघ्यं बल्यं स्तन्यकरंसरम्. Meaning: Cow's milk is the best, life-giving (Jīvanīya), rejuvenative (Rasāyana), beneficial for the wounded, emaciated, and enhances intellect (Medhya). It is sweet, unctuous, pacifies Vāta and Pitta, and is heavy and cold.

Sutra: तक्रं लघु कषायाम्लं दीपनं कफवातजित् । शोफोदरार्शों ग्रहरणीदोषमूत्रग्रहारूचीः.... Meaning: Buttermilk is light (Lagu), astringent and sour, kindles the digestive fire (Dīpana), and conquers Kapha and Vāta. It is beneficial for swelling (Śōtha), abdominal diseases, piles, and Malabsorption (Grahaṇī).

Sutra: शस्तं धीस्मृतिमेधाग्निबलायुः शुक्रचक्षुषाम् । बालवृद्धप्रजाकान्तिसौकुमार्यस्वराथिनाम्. Meaning: Ghee is excellent for intellect, memory, digestive fire (Agni), strength, longevity, semen, and eyes. It is the best of all unctuous substances, extremely cold (Śītam), and the ultimate preserver of age.

Sutra: उष्णमुष्णार्तमुष्णेचयुक्तं चोष्णैनिहन्ति तत्. Meaning: Honey heated on fire (Uṣṇaṃ), honey consumed by one afflicted by heat, honey consumed in the hot season, or honey mixed with hot substances causes death (Nihanti Tat). Exception: Hot honey is not prohibited for emetic (Vamana) or cleansing enema (Nirūhe) because it is quickly expelled.

Sutra: तैलं स्वयोनिवतत्र मुख्यं तीक्ष्णं व्यवायिच । त्वग्दोषकृदक्षुश्यं सूक्ष्मोष्णं कफकन्न च. Meaning: Oil (mainly Sesame) is sharp (Tīkṣṇa), pervasive, subtle, warm, and does not increase Kapha. It is fully capable of nourishing the emaciated and reducing the obese.

Sutra: मासैर्द्धिसंख्यैर्माद्याद्यैः क्रमात् शद्धृतवः स्मृताः। शिशिरोडथ वसन्तश्च ग्रीष्मो वर्शाशद्विमाः. Meaning: The six seasons, in sequence (beginning with Māgha), are: (1) Śiśira (Late Winter), (2) Vasanta (Spring), (3) Grīṣma (Summer), (4) Varṣā (Rainy), (5) Śarad (Autumn), and (6) Hemanta (Early Winter).
Analysis: Vāta accumulates in Grīṣma and aggravates in Prāvṛṭ (Early Monsoon). Pitta accumulates in Varṣā and aggravates in Śarad. Kapha accumulates in Hemanta and aggravates in Vasanta.

Sutra: शिशिराद्यास्त्रिभिस्तैस्तु विद्यादयनमुत्तरम् । आदानं च तदादत्ते नृणां प्रतिदिनं बलम्. Meaning: The three seasons starting with Śiśira (Śiśira, Vasanta, Grīṣma) are Uttarayana, called Ādāna Kāla (Taking Away Period) because the sun and dry wind destroy the earth's mild qualities, and it takes away human strength daily. Dominant Tastes: Bitter in Śiśira, Astringent in Vasanta, Pungent in Grīṣma.

Sutra: वर्षादयो विसर्गश्च यद्वलं विसृजत्ययम् । सौम्यत्वादत्र सोमो हि बलवान् हीयते रविः. Meaning: The three seasons starting with Varṣā (Varṣā, Śarad, Hemanta) are Dakshinayana, called Visarga Kāla (Giving Away Period) because it releases (increases) strength in living beings. The Moon (Soma) is powerful, and the Sun is weak. Dominant Tastes: Sour, Salty, Sweet.

Sutra: शीतेऽग्यं वृष्टिधर्मेऽल्पं बलं मध्यं तु शेषयोः. Meaning: Strength is Excellent (Uttama) during the cold season (Hemanta/Śiśira). Strength is Low (Alpa) during the rainy season and summer (Grīṣma). Strength is Moderate (Madhya) during the remaining two seasons (Śarad and Vasanta).

Sutra: अतः श्रतो हिमेऽस्मिन्सेवेत स्वाद्वम्ललवरगान् रसान्. Meaning: Due to intense digestive fire (Agni), consume foods rich in the Sweet, Sour, and Salty tastes. Eat heavy (Gariṣṭha) and unctuous (Snigdha) foods like jaggery, wheat, black gram, milk products, new grains, fat, and oil.

Sutra: वातघ्नतैलैरम्यगं मूर्धिनं तैलं विमर्दनम् । नियुद्धं कुशलैः सार्द्धं पादाघातं च युक्तितः. Meaning: Practice oil massage (Abhyanga) with Vāta-pacifying oils on the head and body. Engage in wrestling (Niyuddha) and receive a foot massage. Use light, warm clothes and enclosed, heated rooms. Judiciously expose the back to the sun and always wear footwear.
Sutra: अयमेव विधिः कार्यः शिशिरेऽपि विशेषतः. Meaning: All the procedures of Hemanta Ṛtu should be followed, especially in Śiśira Ṛtu, as coldness and dryness (Raukṣya of Ādāna Kāla) increase.

Sutra: कफश्चितो हि शिशिरे वसन्तेऽर्काशुतापित.... Meaning: Kapha accumulated in Śiśira aggravates in Vasanta, destroying Agni and causing Kapha-born diseases. One should quickly conquer excessive Kapha by using strong Emetic (Vamana) and Nasal (Nasya) therapies.

Sutra: तीक्ष्णैर्वमननस्याद्यैर्लघुरुक्षैश्च भोजनैः... गुरूशीतदिवास्वप्नस्निग्धाम्लमधुरांस्त्यजेत्. Meaning: Consume light (Lagu) and dry (Rūkṣa) foods. Eat old barley/wheat, honey, meat from desert animals, and raw mango juice. Avoid heavy, cold, unctuous, sour, and sweet tastes. Avoid day sleep (Divāsvapna).

Sutra: भजेन्मधुरमेवान्नं लघु स्निग्धं हिमं द्रवम्. Meaning: The sun's sharp rays waste Kapha and increase Vāyu. Consume only sweet-taste-dominant (Madhura), light (Lagu), unctuous (Snigdha), cold (Hima), and liquid (Drava) foods. Bathe with cold water and consume Sattu with jaggery/sugar. Avoid: Salty, Pungent, and Sour tastes. Do not consume alcohol, or if necessary, a very small amount mixed with much water.
Sutra: अतस्मिन्पटुकट्वम्लव्यायामार्क करांस्त्यजेत्. Meaning: Avoid Salty (Lavaṇa), Pungent (Kaṭu), and Sour (Amla) tastes, as well as exercise (Vyāyāma) and sun exposure (Ārka Kiraṇān).

Sutra: भजेत्साधारणं सर्वमूष्मरगस्तेजनं च यत् । दिव्यं कौपं श्रृंत चाम्भो भोजनं त्वतिदुर्दिने. Meaning: Agni is weak and vitiated by cold wind, earth vapor, and sour Vipāka. Consume a diet/lifestyle that stimulates heat (Ūṣmaṇā). Drink rainwater, well water, or boiled water (Śṛta Ambu). Food should be light, dry, clearly sour, salty, and unctuous, mixed with honey. Avoid: River water, Sattu, day sleep (Divāsvapna), and excessive exertion.

Sutra: तज्जयाय धृतं तिक्तं विरेको रक्तमोणगम्. Meaning: Pitta accumulated in the rainy season is aggravated by the sudden intense sun. To conquer Pitta, one should perform Purgation (Vireka) and Bloodletting (Raktamokṣaṇa), and consume Bitter Ghee (Tikta Ghṛta).

Sutra: तप्त तप्तांशुकिरणैः शीतं शीतांशुरश्मिभिः । समन्तादप्यहोरात्रमगस्त्योदयनिर्विषम् । शुचि हंसोदकं नाम निर्मलं मलजिज्जलम्. Meaning: Consume light food with Sweet, Bitter, and Astringent tastes. Drink Haṃsodaka (Swan Water), which is purified water detoxified by the Agastya star's rising (heated by day sun, cooled by night moon). Avoid: Dew/spray (Tuṣāra), alkali, excessive eating, curd (Dadhi), oil (Taila), fat (Vasā), sun exposure, strong alcohol, day sleep (Divāsvapna), and wind blowing from the East.

Sutra: ऋत्वोरन्त्यादिसप्ताहावृतुसन्धिरिति स्मृतः । तत्र पूर्वो विधिस्त्याज्यः सेवनीयोऽपरः क्रमात्. Meaning: Ṛtusaṃdhi is the 14 days (seven days at the end of the old season and seven days at the beginning of the new). The regimen of the preceding season should be gradually abandoned, and the regimen of the succeeding season should be gradually adopted. Sudden change can cause diseases.

sutra_name: Qualities of Śāli Rice Varieties (Rakta Śāli)
content (Sutra, Meaning, and Key Analysi: Sutra: रक्तो महान् सकलमस्तूर्णकः शकुनाहृतः.... Meaning: Śāli rice varieties are sweet in taste/Vipāka, unctuous, aphrodisiac, constipating, astringent aftertaste, wholesome, light, diuretic, and cold. Rakta Śāli (Red Rice) is the best, conquering thirst (Tṛṣṇā) and the three Doshas (Tridōṣahā).

Sutra: स्निग्धो ग्राही लघुः स्वादुस्त्रिदोषघ्नः स्थिरो हिमः । शष्टिको व्रीहिषु श्रेष्ठो गोरश्चासित गौरतः. Meaning: Ṣaṣṭika rice (harvested in 60 days) is the best Brīhi grain. It is unctuous, constipating (Grāhī), light (Lagu), sweet, pacifies the three Doshas (Tridōṣaghnaḥ), imparts stability, and is cold.

Sutra: रूक्षः शीतो गुरुः स्वादुः सरो विगवातकृद्यवः ।। वृष्यः स्थैर्यकरो मूत्रमेदः पित्तकफाज्जयेत्. Meaning: Barley is dry (Rūkṣa), cold, heavy, sweet, laxative, and increases Vāyu. It is aphrodisiac, stabilizing, and conquers urinary disorders, fat (Medaḥ), Pitta, and Kapha.

Sutra: वृष्यः शीतो गुरुः स्निग्धों जीवनों वातपितहा ।। सन्धानकारी मधुरो गोधूमः स्थैर्यवृत्सर. Meaning: Wheat is aphrodisiac, cold, heavy, unctuous, life-giving, pacifies Vāta and Pitta, joins broken tissues, sweet, and increases stability.

Sutra: मृद्‌गाढकीमसूरादि शिम्बीधान्यं विबन्धकृत् ।। कशायं स्वादु संग्राहि कटुपाकं हिमं लघु. Meaning: Pulses (Green Gram, Pigeon Pea, Lentil) cause obstruction (Vibandha Kṛt), are astringent/sweet, constipating (Saṅgrāhī), pungent in Vipāka (Kaṭu-pākaṃ), cold, and light. Beneficial for fat, Kapha, blood, and Pitta disorders. Best Pulse: Green Gram (Mudga) is the best and increases Vāyu only slightly.

sutra_name: Qualities of Cooked Foods (Mandā, Peyā, Odana)
content (Sutra, Meaning, and Key Analysi: Sutra: मण्डपेयाविलेपोनामोदनस्य च लाघवम् । तृड्ङ्ग्लानिदोषशेषघ्नः पाचनोधातुसाम्यकृत्. Meaning: Maṇḍa (rice water), Pēyā (thin gruel), Vilēpī (thick gruel), and Odana (cooked rice) are sequentially lighter (Maṇḍa being lightest). Maṇḍa is best: aids digestion (Pācana), balances Dhatus, softens channels, induces sweating, and intensely kindles the digestive fire (Analam).

Sutra: लशुनो भृशतीक्षणोषाः कटुपाकरसः सरः.... Meaning: Garlic is very sharp, hot (Uṣṇa), pungent in taste/Vipāka, laxative, beneficial for the heart, heavy, aphrodisiac, and kindles the digestive fire. Conquers Kapha, Vāta, worms, Gulma, and is a rejuvenative (Rasāyanaṃ). Caution: Pollutes Rakta and Pitta.

Sutra: द्राक्षा फलोत्तमावृव्याचक्षुष्या सृष्टमूत्रविद् ।। स्वादुपाकरसा स्निग्धा सकषाया हिमा गुरुः. Meaning: Grapes are the best among fruits, aphrodisiac, beneficial for the eyes (Cakṣuṣyā), loosen stool/urine, sweet in taste/Vipāka, unctuous, slightly astringent, cold, and heavy. Destroys Vāta, Pitta, blood disorders, thirst, cough, and wasting.

Sutra: उद्रिक्तपित्ताच्जयति त्रोन्दोषान्स्वादु दाडिमम् ।। पित्ताविरोधि नात्युष्णमम्लं वातकफापहम्. Meaning: Sweet Pomegranate conquers the three Doshas and increased Pitta. Sour Pomegranate pacifies Vāta and Kapha and does not oppose Pitta. All Pomegranates are beneficial for the heart, light, unctuous, binding (Grāhī), and kindles the digestive fire.

Sutra: पक्कं सुदुर्जरं बिल्वं दोषलं पूतिमारूतम् । दीपनं कफवातघ्नं बालं ग्राह्युमयं च तत्. Meaning: Ripe Wood Apple is very difficult to digest and aggravates Doshas. Unripe Wood Apple kindles the digestive fire and pacifies Kapha and Vāta. Both are binding/constipating (Grāhi).

Sutra: वातपित्तास्त्रकृद्वाल, बद्धास्थिकफपित्तकृत् । गुर्वाभ्रं वातजित्पक्वं स्वाद्वम्लं कफशुक्रकृत्. Meaning: Very raw mango aggravates Vāta, Pitta, and blood. Raw (with stone) aggravates Kapha and Pitta. Ripe sweet mango is heavy and pacifies Vāta. Ripe sour mango increases Kapha and Śukra.

Sutra: हिमानलोणादुर्वातव्याललालाऽऽदिदूषितम् ।। जन्तुजुष्टं जले मग्नमभूमिजमनार्तवम्. Meaning: Avoid grains and vegetables contaminated by frost, fire, strong wind, saliva of venomous animals, insects, submerged in water, grown in unsuitable land, or grown out of season. Avoid all raw fruits except for Wood Apple (Bilva-varjitam).
